It's entirely healthy and probably good for our pensions.

BE

The bots that now control flow haven't read those banal traders memoirs, which is a good thing. Though I guess they might write some, eventually, which'd be a bad thing.

BE

Oddo to tell us this is good news, perhaps, providing Opec does what it's never done before and actually sticks to an agreement.

11:11 am
BE

The informal OPEC meeting that was held yesterday in Algiers managed, against all
expectation, to reach an agreement on a reduction in production to between 32.5 and
33Mb/d, i.e. a reduction of 0.5 to 1Mb/d vs the August production level. OPEC has issued no
detail on quota by country and a committee is working on this and we expect an
announcement at the next official meeting on 30 November. That said, this announcement
constitutes a reversal in the trend and a major inflection in OPEC’s position, which suggests
that the cartel, and notably Saudi Arabia needs to shore-up prices in the short term. Indeed,
Saudi Arabia which decided two years ago now to increase its production in a bid to side-line
producers with high production costs (i.e. shale oil) has now changed its strategy. Its budget
deficit has deepened by $ 100bn per annum (to the point at which the wages of public sector
workers have been cut). Moreover, Saudi Arabia has accepted that Iran will return to
production levels of 4Mb/d. Indeed, Iran is currently producing 3.6Mb/d and even hopes to
achieve 4-4.2Mb/d. This agreement, the first in eight years, has resulted in a 5.9% increase
to $ 48.7/b.

BE

The absence of quantified quotas by country is likely to maintain uncertainty until end-
November. We estimate the current surplus at 700kb/d for Q4 2016 and Q1-Q2 2017, indeed
the call on OPEC is at 32.8Mb/d, well below OPEC's current production which totals
33.5Mb/d. Therefore the announced reduction to 32.5-33Mb/d should help to rebalance the
market in the short term. As of Q3 2017, the increase in demand (+1.2Mb/d) should take
over, leading to a more fundamental market equilibrium with a call of OPEC of 33.6Mb/d.
This could create room for around 800kb/d in additional production from Libya and Iran. For
the time being, no per-country quota has been decided but after negotiations Iran, Libya and
Nigeria should be exempt from quotas. On our estimates, Saudi Arabia could rapidly reduce
its production by 500kb/d given that this is the customary reduction at the end of the summer
(when production increases due to the need for air conditioning). That said, an agreement
with Iraq, where production has increased by 1Mb/d over the past two years might not be
respected notably in the autonomous Kurdistan region which does not follow decisions made
by central government. A swifter or more robust increase in production by Libya or Iran
before Q2 2017 would be undesirable and it is here that OPEC could request support from
Russia, which was strongly in favour of this agreement.

BE

This context prompts us to think that the low point has been reached, thus limiting
speculation and short positions on oil in the short term. That said, it does not prompt us to
alter our oil price scenario of $ 40/50/60/b in 2016/2017/2018, respectively. We think that
production costs in the industry have fallen, new projects in conventional oil are now
profitable at $ 50/b, likewise for shale oil at around $ 50-60/b, which should limit the increase
in the oil price. For this reason, our long-term price remains capped at $ 60/b (vs $ 70/b for
the consensus) which is the price necessary to cover the marginal cost of production in tar
sands. This announcement should be highly advantageous to those oil companies that have
slashed costs and cash breakeven and, notably, Eni and RD Shell which offer amongst the
highest sensitivity to the oil price

Weir Group PLC (WEIR:LSE): Last: 1,655, up 84 (+5.35%), High: 1,663, Low: 1,605, Volume: 503.41k

11:13 am
Amec Foster Wheeler PLC (AMFW:LSE): Last: 574.50, up 32 (+5.90%), High: 591.00, Low: 573.50, Volume: 934.84k
BE

MOST on Weir.

BE

Conclusion – Positive catalyst for Weir: As we highlighted in our recent note
"Weir: Consensus Underestimating Recovery Potential – OW", within Capital
Goods, US oil services exposed Weir is our top pick as we are 11%/33% ahead of
consensus estimates in 2017/18. This is on the back of a recovery in mining
replacement capex but also an inflection in 2017/18 in US oil rig count, to which
Weir is 88% correlated. Oil prices drive rig count, rig count drives Weir's O&G
growth and margins track growth. We see today's announcement as a clear
positive catalyst for Weir's O&G business. Our US Oil Services team forecasts rig
count growth of 71.6%/58.9% for 2017/18, which supports our above consensus
recovery in O&G division orders.
We also prefer Oil Services over Mid/Downstream O&G exposure. Our
proprietary capex tracker shows in that Oil Services capex has fallen much
further (-67% vs peak) than mid/downstream conventional capex (0 to -10%) and
capex / depreciation levels are much lower in upstream than in mid/downstream
segments. With around 30% upside potential to PT and estimates that are
11%/33% ahead of consensus in 2017/18 we are OW.

There have been many, many, many concerns raised about the way Capita adds up the numbers. This is very likely to revive some of those.

BE

Sellside coming through now the call's finished. Here's Caz

BE

Today’s release not only reduces profit expectations, but also underlines the complexity of Capita’s business and the risk that there are more structurally challenged businesses in Capita’s very wide portfolio business model.

11:23 am
BE

Divisional trading slowdown seen in three main areas: The IT Enterprise Services (ITES) business, particularly Technology Solutions (a reselling business for technology), the Specialist Recruitment business in Workplace Services (WS), and the Asset Services division following the EU Referendum in the UK. For ITES and Workplace Services there has been a c. £100-150m revenue reduction (vs. mgmt expectations) and £30m underlying PBT reduction. The slowdown in ITES is also seen as a company specific issue, with the market continuing to be more robust. Capita’s Tech Solutions business made £35-40m profit in 2015, and was expected to make £50m in FY16, however they now believe it will be closer to £30m. The remaining £10m profit reduction from IT Services and Specialist Recruitment is from recruitment and the broader IT Services business. Management commented that the slowdown in Specialist Recruitment is structural, with its business not keeping pace with changes in the procurement of recruitment particularly in the Education sector, as such Capita will be undertaking widespread restructuring in that business. Asset Services is expected to achieve £5-6m lower profitability as a result of slower activity in financial markets. The most concerning aspect of today’s trading update is the admission that it is materially underperforming in some of its markets, with some of the issues likely to persist.

BE

Contract issues. There has been delays on the implementation of the IT system in the Transport for London congestion charging contract, and Capita expects £20-25m costs related to this. These costs are split 50/50 between penalties and the cost of running teams for longer. Capita has £949m major contract sales wins in 2016, however sales in 2H16 are now expected to be lower, due to delays in decision making and lower conversion of the pipeline. The decision on the large Defence Fire and Rescue contract (c. £600m for Capita) has moved from 4Q to 1Q, Capita has also lost a large Life and Pensions contract, and there have been further slippage in decisions in Germany. The conversion of the pipeline is expected to be c. 30% for FY16. Capita also commented that the c. £400m contract with the NHS Primary Care Support Services has faced some challenges which was a small part of today’s profit reduction, however Capita remains confident it can deliver.

BE

Net debt/EBITDA expected to be 2.7x, but lease adjusted closer to 3x. The net debt is expected to be similar to the £1,901m seen at the end of June. Management commented that there are c. £600m of lease commitments (most of which are property) and annual rent cost of £140m. This would take lease adjusted net debt to c. £2,500m, and ND/EBITDA of c. 3.0x. Capita’s debt is private, and does not take account of the lease payments for the tests. However, this does seem to rule out the opportunity to tap the public debt markets in the short term. Capita has some leverage requirements in large contracts, however they are still someway off these. Capita intends to do some, but limited M&A for the rest of 2016 and 2017. Management also expects to maintain the dividend policy which is usually dividend cover of 2.2x.

11:24 am
BE

And Kean Marden at Jefferies.

BE

Feedback from the Capita conference call: 1) Despite similarities now (negative organic
revenue growth and 2.7x ND/EBITDA), they believe they don’t need an equity issue,
stressing that, in retrospect, the 2012 equity issue wasn’t necessary and they don’t believe
leverage impacts bid pipeline conversion; 2) They reiterated their commitment to the
dividend, which is important given the 4.8% yield at 675p; 3) Trading issues mostly relate
to the transactional businesses (recruitment, technology reselling and shareholder register,
which we pre-emptively downgraded post the EU referendum but clearly not by enough),
plus a performance issue with TFL.

BE

Our initial calculations suggest mid-60s EPS in FY16E and not much higher in FY17E, using
stated company guidance. If a £500-600m equity raise is required to reduce ND/EBITDA
down to 2.0x this would be c8% dilutive. So at 675p, this worst case scenario would leave
the shares trading on c11x FY17E PE, a c8% FCF yield and 4.8% dividend yield.

PM

We pride ourselves on working with the foremost technology innovators in the world

and that's why we are so excited to announce a strategic alliance with GE today. This novel partnership expands our already vast network of research and development partners. The two entities agree to invest in new and existing technologies sourced from both Allied Minds' and GE's innovation pipeline across healthcare, transportation, energy, and big data, among others.

As part of the alliance, GE receives an option to participate in any future capital raise by Allied Minds plc, subject to current pre-emption rights, applicable authorizations, laws and regulations. GE will also benefit from the opportunity to invest in some of our current subsidiaries and any new ones set up to commercialize IP sourced from our network of over 160 university and federal research partners.

This is a landmark partnership with a globally-renowned leader in innovation. It is a validation of our model and testament to the potential of our current portfolio. It gives us access to a new potential investor and strengthens the pipeline through access to GE's innovations and IP. It's the very embodiment of a symbiotic relationship and we're excited to see what amazing things happen when we put our combined businesses (and resources) to work.

The CMA has today launched a market study into digital comparison tools to see how they are working for consumers, business and the economy.

PM

11:34 am
BE

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will study the digital comparison tools (DCTs) which enable consumers to compare products and services on quality as well as price, and help them switch between suppliers. These range from price comparison websites (PCWs) to smartphone apps.

The CMA’s reviews of sectors such as private motor insurance, energy and banking have highlighted how these tools can play a powerful role in increasing competition and helping consumers to find better deals and switch. This new study will consider how to maximise the potential benefits of DCTs for consumers, and reduce any barriers to how they work.

BE

It's been one of our themes on here for a while to ponder aloud who benefits from price comparison sites.

BE

As in, they're businesses that make an amazing amount from hidden commission fees.

11:35 am

BE

Our view: We believe that this investigation is a natural evolution of previous studies into the space and whilst it is hard to predict what the outcomes will likely be we doubt the results will impede the ongoing structural growth seen within the PCW industry although we acknowledge that any uncertainty is unlikely to be taken well. We'd flag the supportive commentary from the CMA CEO and would also specifically highlight comments around the varying degrees of success in price comparison across different sectors. With switching levels particularly low in energy & communications we believe this could bode well for home services switching. We'd flag that ZPG (OP,390p) obtains 50% of its revenues from home
services switching and MONY (OP, 400p) obtains 17% of its revenues.

BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

The
purpose of the review is to provide a definite assessment of the
role of digital comparison tools (DCT), to determine how to
maximise the benefits that DCT can deliver and to reduce
barriers to the effective functions of DCTs There remains an
element of consumer mistrust, centred on the apparent tension
between deriving a commercial profit from saving consumers
money. We expect the CMA will look in detail at disclosure and
commercial execution. Money supermarket has welcomed this
review. In our opinion this review has the capacity to provide a
definitive endorsement of the PCW markets whilst tightening up
the methods of working. This should be a benefit to the
established large players. However, any regulatory review has
the capacity to uncover poor practices which at the margin
impact all players. This uncertainty will persist through this
review period.

Key takeaways from today's update, FY16. Five key takeaways we think:
1. Restructuring the business. The new senior management team getting to
work, 'reorganisation initiatives being implemented', the aim, greater strategic
focus, more effective decision making and improved financial performance; there
will be headcount reductions. Bigger exceptional charge this year than expected,
now c.£50m, was £15m in May 2016;
2. In-line print, FY16 outlook confirmed. Group underlying revenue growth of
+0%, H116 -1%, B2B +2%, H116 +1%, DMG Media -2%, -3% at H116;
3. Net debt/EBITDA remains conservative. Below x2.0 by year-end.
4. DMG B2B, a US$ beneficiary. Reported revenue growth well ahead of
underlying, at Group +9% versus underlying at +2%, RMS, +10% versus +1%,
Information, +16% versus +6% and Events +13% versus +2%; and
5. The DMG Media dynamic, unchanged. Underlying revenue -2%, circulation
revenues -2%, advertising revenues -4%, print -12%, digital +17%. Advertising
revenues down -10% since 21 August, balanced somewhat by an extra week of

BE

BE

We expected £5m from disposals in aggregate for FY17E so this is slightly better than anticipated, though we had expected the disposal to be Pure in isolation. Pure was in discontinued operations for FY17E so there is no meaningful revenue or profit impact here. However, this is another sign of new management doing the right thing in disposing of a division that lost money for eight consecutive years and had no real relevance to IP licensing. IMG’s property assets (greater than £50m) form a minor part of our SOTP valuation, so how granting an option on one property affects this remains to be clarified in due course.

BE

The statement also suggests Q1 trading is in line with expectations with no further detail. FY17E will be a back-end loaded year – this is normally the case, with the December quarter important for Apple units, but Mediatek share regain will also only start showing through in calendar Q1 at the earliest. In addition, the licence pipeline may take time to rebuild through the year. A heavy H2 skew is nothing new for Imagination, but catalysts at the H1 results will likely have to be in the words rather than numbers.

11:57 am
BE

We remain at Buy with our TP under review. The shares will probably pause for breath after a good run of late; our basic view remains that the current level is justified on forecasts as they stand on a SOTP basis, but the GPU financials are in the trough and share (re)gain within Mediatek and other Asian SoC vendors offers potentially significant upside on a longer-term view, i.e. FY18E and beyond.

The consideration for the Pure business is a little
less than expectations, which were in the £5-10m range, however the delta is
somewhat immaterial. The Pure business had been classified as for sale by the
new management team as it had been consistently loss making. A brief update on
trading is also given, saying that performance in Q1 is "in-line with expectations".
The sale of other non-core cash consuming activities is progressing with on-going
discussions with several interested parties and a small part of IMG Systems was
sold earlier in September for minimal consideration. The stock has rallied strongly
in recent months, with the acquisition of ARM by Softbank the main identifiable
catalyst, increasing focus on the strategic value of the PowerVR graphics business
(which is a key strategic technology used by Apple). We move our target price to
280p from 220p, now putting it in-line with our sum-of-the-parts valuation. Given
the rally in the stock we move recommendation to Add from Buy.

PM

Someone was asking for macro earlier

PM

12:00 pm
PM

Here's the cover page

PM

Downside risks from Brexit and China that preoccupied us in June have not materialized. We have upgraded our forecasts in both areas and also see a stronger H2 for the US after a weak H1. Meanwhile, the emergence of an outspokenly dovish wing of the FOMC should temper concern over Fed tightening for the near future.
The medium-term outlook is not very inspiring for growth-sensitive assets. Despite our upgrades, we expect the world economy to grow just 3.5% in 2017, with risk to the downside. And after years of QE, few markets are cheap. But with global growth likely solid over the next few months, monetary policy ultra-easy, and the equity risk premium elevated, we move to a more risk-tolerant stance at the start of Q4.
We recommend that investors moderately overweight global stocks and underweight safe-haven bonds, with a market-weight on corporate credit. Within equities, we favour euro area and EM over Japan and the UK, and recommend a market weight on the US. Within safe-haven fixed income, we favour US debt over the euro area and Japan. We also have a moderate overweight on US corporate credit over Europe, with the credit portfolio drifting toward riskier IG names and higher-quality high yield.

PM

EM stock and bond markets are unlikely to repeat the outperformance of Q3. But most emerging countries are natural beneficiaries of our economic outlook: no near-term China weakness, stabilizing commodities markets, an ever-slower Fed hiking cycle, and room to ease local policy rates. Despite the recent outperformance, we recommend being overweight EM USD debt and parts of EM local currency debt, in addition to EM equities.
Politics should continue to be a market focus, given rising populist/nationalist rhetoric in the US and Europe. But we do not expect market-unfriendly actions by any governments in 2016. Political risks could be more material next year, when the UK government has indicated it will trigger Article 50 and amid elections in the Netherlands, France and Germany.
Central banks should remain supportive of asset markets, but operational and political constraints are now more apparent. Scarcity of assets for further QE, political backlash against further negative rates, and problems for banking systems due to very flat yield curves – these could all be headaches for the ECB and BoJ in 2017.

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has instituted criminal proceedings against Mark Alexander Lyttleton (date of birth 9 June 1971), a former Investment Portfolio Manager at Blackrock Investment Management (UK) Ltd. Mr Lyttleton is charged with three counts of insider dealing, contrary to Section 52(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 1993.

The offences relate to trading in equities and a call option between 2 October 2011 and 16 December 2011.

Mr Lyttleton has been summonsed to attend City of London Magistrates’ Court on 29th September 2016.
